coredata.dc:title: Utilization of cereal-based husks to achieve sustainable development goals: Treatment of wastewater, biofuels, and biodegradable packaging

coredata.dc:description:
Background Food waste management (FWM) has gained much attention over the past few years in industries, research institutions, and national and international organizations due to its significant potential to produce valuable products and control environmental pollution. Finding the sustainable approaches to utilize these waste materials is a current focus of many researchers.
Scope and approach This review aims to explore the potential of cereal-based husks from 5 major cereal grains (wheat, rice, corn, barley, and millet) to achieve goals 6 (clean water and sanitation), 7 (affordable and clean energy), 9 (industry, innovation, and infrastructure), and 12 (responsible consumption and production) of the 17 sustainable development goals (SDGs) set out by the united nations to make the world more healthy and developed with minimum environmental pollution.
Key findings and conclusion Cereal-based husks can be utilized to make adsorbents to remove heavy metals, dyes, antibiotics, pesticides, and petrol contaminants from wastewater. These husks can be utilized to produce clean and affordable energy alternatives such as biogas (methane), organic bio-oil, biodiesel, and bioethanol. Moreover, the biopolymeric matrices of these husks can be efficiently used to make bioplastics, biocomposite films, biodegradable foams, and packaging paper for food and other industries.

row.entry: Cereal-based husks
Techniques/methods used
Preparation of biosorbent/adsorbent
Pollutants removed
Cleaning remarks
Overall findings
References
Adsorption of RB 19 and RB 195 dyes by using WH adsorbent

The WHs were cleaned, dried, and ground into powder form. To extract the pigments, powdered material was soaked in HNO3, then washed, dried, and weighed again before being stored in a desiccator until needed. The adsorbent was produced from pretreated WHs.
RB 19 and RB 195 dyes
WH is one of the substances that can be utilized in the elimination of RB 19 and RB 195 from wastewater because it is readily available and suitable for the production of adsorbent from it.

Initial RB 19 and RB 195 concentrations, contact time, temperature, and pH all affect the adsorption of RB 19 and RR 195 by WH adsorbents. With an increase in pH and an increase in dye ion concentration, the adsorption capacity was also increased.
Preparation of an adsorbent by modification of WHB with CA

WHB was produced by pyrolyzing of WHs in a muffle furnace for 2Â h at 800Â Â°C. CA was used to modify WHB at different impregnation percentages of 2.5, 5, 7.5 and 10% (WHB/CA, W/W), and the mixture was then magnetically stirred for 2Â h at a temperature of 25Â Â°C.
MB dye and CIP antibiotic
It demonstrated the effectiveness, novelty, and affordability of WHB/CA as an adsorbent for the treatment of wastewater.
The maximum adsorption capacity of WHC/CA was 94.03% for CIP and 299.493Â mg/g for MB.
Preparation of an adsorbent by using WHs
The WHs were cleaned, dried, and crushed at 125Â Â°C for 2Â h to produce the WH sorbent material and stored at ambient temperature.
Congo Red (a carcinogenic dye)
For the removal of Congo red from aqueous solutions, the WH is thought to be a relatively inexpensive natural sorbent.

With increasing adsorbent dosage and reducing particle size, the percentage of dye eliminated increased. The maximum removal and uptake for 25 initial concentrations, pH 6.7, and 1.5Â g/L WH dosage was 21.5Â mg/g (91%).
Preparation of an adsorbent after pretreatment of husks from buckwheat with H2SO4.
By using H2SO4, the husks of buckwheatÂ (Fagopyrum esculentum) were treated. The 2,4-D pesticide was then eliminated from aqueous solutions using modified husks of buckwheat as an adsorbent.
2,4-D (a herbicide)
H2SO4 was successfully used to modify WHs and effectively applied to remove the 2,4-D herbicide from the aqueous effluents.
45% of 2,4-D was removed by using an adsorbent prepared from modified husks of buckwheat.
Preparation of an adsorbent from RH ash and application of batch adsorption technique to remove heavy metals
The RHP was cleaned and dried in sunlight and an oven. It was then modified with 0.1Â N HCl to produce an adsorbent for heavy metal ion removal.
Cr, Pb, and Zn metal ions
RHP can be used as a low-cost, efficient, and eco-friendly adsorbent for removing heavy metal ions from industrial effluents.

For 25Â mg/L of Cr, Pb, and Zn metal ion solutions, the maximum adsorption efficiency was achieved at a contact time of 1Â h, a temperature of 30Â Â°C, a pH of 6.0, and 2.5Â g/L of adsorbent dosage. The amount of Cr, Pb, and Zn metal ions removed by the adsorbent were 87.12%, 88.63%, and 99.28% respectively.
Preparation of an adsorbent from RHs after pretreatment of RHs with NaOH

To make RHP, the rice hulls were gathered from nearby mills, cleaned, dried, crushed, and sieved. To create the adsorbent material, the powder was subjected to treatment with 1Â M NaOH and then washed and dried.
Metal ions including Be2+, Al3+, Cr3+, Co2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Sr2+, Ag+, Cd2+, Ba2+, and Pb2+
Acid or base treatments on hulls of rice can greatly increase their adsorption capacity and effectiveness.

When compared to untreated hulls of rice, NaOH treatment significantly increased the effectiveness of metal ions removal. The treated hulls of rice are a desirable adsorbent for pre-concentration, removal, and recovery of low-level metal ions because they have quick removal kinetics for several metal ions.
Preparation of an adsorbent from RHs and orange peel

The orange peels were washed, dried in the oven, ground, and sieved. RHs were also cleaned, dried, ground, and sieved. The powder of RHs and powder of orange peels were mixed to produce an adsorbent for the removal of Cu & Ni.
Cu & Ni
While RHs alone were ineffective at removing Cu and Ni from wastewater, it was effective when combined with orange peel to produce an adsorbent.

At concentrations of 1â11 g/100Â mL, cheap adsorbents like RHs and orange peel were efficient at removing heavy metals. The ideal pH range for heavy metal adsorption was basic pH, and the best rotational speed for removing metal ions was between 50 and 200 RPM. When RHs and orange peels were combined, 99.1% of Cu and 99.36% of Ni were removed.
Preparation of RHB for the removal of MB dye by performing batch experiments
RHs were cleaned and dried and RHB was prepared through the process of slow pyrolysis at 500Â Â°C.
MB dye
The removal of textile dyes and colorants from wastewater can be possible using by using RHB as an adsorbent.
The removal efficiency of MB by RHB ranged from 71 to 99% at pH 2â11.
RHs were modified by various physical and chemical treatments to make MRH that was used as an adsorbent to remove textile dyes.

The biomass was cleaned before being dried for 5 days in the air and then for 24Â h in a 70Â Â°C oven. The dried biomass was ground, sieved, and treated with HCl and some other chemicals to produce MRH.
Textile dyes including Ever direct Orange-3GL, Direct Orange-26, Direct Red-31, Direct Blue-67 and Direct Orange-26 dyes
To remove dyes from textile effluents, it was advised to use acidic pre-treated RHs.
Even after being subjected to treatments with salts, surfactants, and alkalis, RH biomass treated with HCl showed high efficiency in adsorbing EDO-3, DR-31, DO-26, and DB-67 dyes.
Preparations of XRH and CRH for the removal of CV dye by performing batch experiments.

Concentrated H2SO4 was added to raw RHs until they turned black, then the material was allowed to react for 24Â h to produce charcoal. The charcoal was cleaned with de-ionized water, dried, and then ground and sieved before being dried in an oven at 80Â Â°C. The finished product, CRH, was kept in a desiccator and was prepared for experimentation or further tinkering.
CV dye
The effectiveness of RHs in removing CV dye from tainted aqueous solutions can be improved chemically by treating them with H2SO4.
The ability of CV dye to bind to CRH and XRH at pH 10 was shown to be 62.85Â mg/g and 90.02Â mg/g, respectively.
Modification of polysulfone by the incorporation of CDs and SiO2 synthesized from RHs for dyes from wastewater.
Through hydrothermal synthesis, CD/SiO2 composite was produced using CDs and SiO2 from RHs. Several UF membranes with embedded CD/SiO2 composite were prepared.
Tartrazine dye
It is possible to produce membranes with a high permeability and dye removal efficiency by using CDs and SiO2 synthesized from RHs.
The 2.5Â wt% CD/SiO2 membrane showed the highest dye removal rate of 50.54%.
Preparation of RHB for the removal of BR09 and BB41 dyes from aqueous solutions

At various temperatures (300, 350, 400, 450, and 500Â Â°C), RH biomass was pyrolyzed slowly under optimum pyrolysis conditions. To produce RHB with uniform particle size, the material was ground and sieved.
BR09 and BB41
The removal of dyes from wastewater using RHB was found to be a successful and environmentally friendly process.
Under ideal conditions, RHB was able to remove 80% of the BB41 and BR09 dyes.
Preparation of CTAB functionalized nano silica by using RHs for the removal of Beta-lactam amoxicillin antibiotic.
CTAB was adsorbed onto the RH-based nano-silica to improve its functionality and antibiotic adsorption ability.
Beta-lactam amoxicillin antibiotic
CTAB functionalized nano-silica is a superior adsorbent for the removal of antibiotics from aqueous solutions.
For Beta-lactam amoxicillin, CTAB functionalized nanosilica achieved 100% removal efficiency while using nanosilica without CTAB only achieved a removal efficiency of 25.1%.

Extraction of nano-silica from RHs and adsorption of poly (3-methacryloylamino propyl-trimethylammonium chloride) on RH-based nano-silica for efficient removal of Beta-lactam cefixime an antibiotic from wastewater.
A new adsorbent known as polycation-coated nano-silica was produced by poly (3-methacryloylamino propyl-trimethylammonium chloride) adsorption on RH-based nano-silica.
Beta-lactam cefixime an antibiotic

Antibiotics can be effectively removed from wastewater using a novel adsorbent made of RH-based nano-silica and pre-adsorbed with poly (3-methacryloylamino propyl-trimethylammonium chloride). To address the issue of antibiotic contamination in wastewater treatment, this hybrid adsorbent is a useful tool.
More than 85% of Beta-lactam cefixime was removed from hospital wastewater by using polycation-coated nano-silica as an adsorbent.
Preparation of pure silica nanostructures from RHs to remove CIP from polluted wastewater.

For extraction of silica from RHs, the husks were first acid-leached before being extracted with a 2Â M NaOH solution. Once the pH of the solution reached 4, 5, and 7, strong acids like H2SO4 and HNO3 were added to begin the silica gel precipitation process.
CIP antibiotic
The generated SiO2 nanoparticles showed a potent capacity to adsorb and excrete CIP antibiotics.
SiO2 nanoparticles were found to have a high capacity to remove CIP antibiotics from water-based solutions.
Preparation of CH and RH biochars for the removal of heavy metals from wastewater
Biochars were produced by pyrolyzing husks of corn and rice at temperatures of 500, 600, and 700Â Â°C to treat low-quality industrial wastewater.
Cr, Fe, and Pb
The biochars made from husks of rice and corn could remove heavy metal ions from industrial wastewater; RHB had a higher capacity than CHB.

The less removal of Cr and Pb was obtained when CHs were carbonized at 600Â Â°C (only 20% and slightly more than 35%). For Cr (65%), Fe (90%), and Pb (>90%), carbonization of RHs at 600Â Â°C led to the best removal efficiencies.
Modification of CH leaves with bismuthiol I to prepare an adsorbent for the removal of Hg (II) from wastewater
CH leaves were treated with bismuthiol I to prepare an adsorbent.
Hg(II)
In terms of sustainability, the adsorbent prepared from the CH leaves can be used to remove Hg from wastewater.
At pH 1.0â7.0, the Hg removal efficiency was greater than 98.5%.
Preparation of CHAC as an adsorbent to remove phenol andÂ p-nitrophenol from aqueous solutions

CH powder was treated with FeCl3 solution, stirred, and then kept overnight. Vacuum filtration was used to remove the extra iron solution, and an oven was used to dry the material. The material was heated to temperatures of 250 and 500Â Â°C before being cleaned, dried, and homogenized for use in the adsorption of phenol and p-nitrophenol.
Phenol and p-nitrophenol
Phenol and p-nitrophenol were removed effectively by the synthesized adsorbents.

The CHAC-500 was more efficient than the CHAC-250. In comparison to CHAC-250 which had maximum phenol p-nitrophenol and adsorptions of 81% and 84%, respectively. CHAC-500 had maximum phenol p-nitrophenol and adsorptions of 96% and 94%.
Preparation of a magnetized activated carbon from BHs as an adsorbent that was magnetized with Fe3O4 and modified with thiol for efficient removal of Hg (II) from wastewater.

Activated carbon was produced from beer barley husks using a dual-stage chemical activation process. Fe3O4 was added to the barley husk to magnetize it, followed by thiol-modification using a facile and safe hydrothermal method. The resulting product was a thiol magnetic activated carbon adsorbent.
Hg (II)
After five consecutive cycles of adsorption-desorption for the removal of Hg (II), the prepared adsorbent can be used again and again with little or no loss of adsorption capacity.

The highest Hg (II) removal rate of approximately 99.44% was observed under ideal conditions, which included a pH of 6, a Hg (II) concentration of about 20Â mg/L, an adsorbent dose of 0.4Â g/L, and a contact time of 60Â min.
Preparation of magnetic nano-silica from BHs as adsorbent for the removal of petrol contaminants from polluted water.

Following a low-energy and sustainable process of acid reflux and heat treatment, the BH waste was utilized as a precursor for the synthesis of nano-silica. After that, magnetic nano-silica was produced using nano-silica and a magnetic solution of Fe3O4 nanoparticles.
Petrol contaminants

As a sorbent for petroleum and its byproducts from contaminated water, magnetic nano-silica can be made using environmentally friendly processes that have the necessary properties to increase environmental sustainability.
On a 40Â mg/L concentration of petroleum, only 0.6 gm of magnetic nano-silica was used, and the experiments showed a high uptake efficiency of 85%.
Preparation of an adsorbent from MHs after pretreatment with H2SO4.

Adsorbents were synthesized by thermal and chemical treatments of GMH called thermally treated GMH and chemically treated GHM. GMH was first treated with H2SO4 which increased its porosity and homogeneity.
Cr(VI)
The desorption study revealed that thermally treated GMH and chemically treated GHM give 69.45% and 74.48% removal of Cr(VI) respectively up to the six cycles.

Under certain conditions (25Â mg/L Cr(VI) solution, 4Â g/L adsorbent dose, 25Â Â°C temperature, and 150âRPM shaking speed), the maximum removal of Cr(VI) was 16Â mg/g by using thermally treated GMH occurred at a pH of 1 and contact time of 150Â min. On the other hand, for chemically treated GHM, the maximum removal of Cr(VI) was 22.21Â mg/g achieved at a pH of 2 and a contact time of 120Â min.
Preparation of Ag-NPs from MHs and removal of algae from wastewater by using that Ag-NPs.

Ag-NPs were biologically synthesized by using husks of pearl millet (Pennisetum glaucum)
.
Algae

A cost-effective and environmentally friendly process was developed to remove algae in wastewater for water-stressed areas in Namibia/Africa. In addition, the effectiveness of using Ag-NP doped charcoal as a catalyst for the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde was also demonstrated.

Ag-NPs synthesized through biological means were found to be toxic to algae, resulting in a 41.31% reduction in chlorophyll concentration. The study also confirmed the successful conversion of benzyl alcohol to benzaldehyde using Ag-NPs doped on the charcoal catalyst, with 90% conversion. Ag-NPs can be used for algae control in wastewater and as a catalyst for oxidation reactions.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Utilization of cereal-based husks for the production of biofuels.

row.entry: Cereal-based husks
Techniques used
Necessary treatments/conditions
Types of biofuels obtained
Characteristics
Outcomes
References
Anaerobic digestion of WHs after LD soaking pretreatment
The particle size of WHsÂ =Â 2, 5, and 8Â mm, soaking pretreatment timeÂ =Â 1, 3, and 5 days, and temperatureÂ =Â 37Â Â°C.
Methane (biogas)
A higher yield of methane was obtained after LD soaking pretreatment
A maximum methane yield of 130.0Â mL/g VS was obtained by using the LD soaking pretreatment which was 91% more as compared to the initial 68Â mL/g VS yield.
TCR of WHs

The feedstock was heated at a rate of 1Â Â°C/s to an intermediate pyrolysis temperature of 350â450Â Â°C, condensed with cooling water, and cooled to 5Â Â°C before being processed at a rate of up to 1.4Â kg/h.
Organic bio-oil
Organic bio-oil contains an HHV, Phenol was high in amount and the most prevalent long-chain hydrocarbon found was oleic acid.
5.7% of bio-oil, 29.5% of synthesis gas, 21.7% of char, and 32.8% of aqueous phase liquids were obtained.
Thermophilic anaerobic co-digestion of WHs
Particle size: 2â5Â mm, 1:1 mixing ratio, and â20Â Â°C temperature.
Methane (biogas)
Higher biogas yield and process stability were obtained
The samples in which GAC and granular biochar GBC were added produced 22 and 27% more yield of biogas as compared to the control sample.
(S. B. Tiwari et al., 2021)
Doping of RH biochar with K2O and NiO by impregnation techniques to produce nano-catalyst
RHs were oven-dried at 105Â Â°C, Charred at 450Â Â°C for 3Â h, and pyrolyzed at 600Â Â°C for 3Â h
Biodiesel
The biodiesel production was increased by using a bifunctional magnetic nano-catalyst produced from RH biochar
The highest biodiesel yield of 98.2% was attained by using 4Â wt% of catalyst loading. Up to 5 reaction cycles using the same catalyst 70% biodiesel was obtained.
Doping of RH with K2O and Fe by wet impregnation method to produce nano-bifunctional catalyst
Catalyst amountÂ =Â 4Â wt%, methanol/oil molar ratioÂ =Â 12:1, temperatureÂ =Â 75Â Â°C, and timeÂ =Â 4Â h
Biodiesel
A high yield of biodiesel was obtained by using a nano-bifunctional catalyst.
The maximum yield of biodiesel obtained by using a nano-bifunctional catalyst was 98.6%.
Transesterification of Jatropha oil and blending with RH nanoparticles to produce biodiesel

After the seeds were dried to remove moisture, jatropha oil was extracted from the seeds using mechanical expellers. During the trans-esterification procedure, the density of fatty acids was eliminated and biodiesel was produced. RHs were processed through ball-milling to produce nanoparticles.
Jatropha methyl ester-diesel blend
Better combustion characteristics, improved performance characteristics, reduced fuel consumption, and less exhaust emissions were observed.
A 20% Jatropha methyl ester-diesel blend that contains 0.2% RH nanoparticles enhances performance and reduces exhaust emissions.
Esterification of palm PFAD and using RH ash NiSO4/SiO2 catalyst to enhance the production of biodiesel
Catalyst amountÂ =Â 15%, methanol:PFAD molar ratioÂ =Â 5:1, timeÂ =Â 7Â h
Biodiesel
A higher extraction yield of biodiesel was obtained by using RH ash NiSO4/SiO2 catalyst
The highest methyl esters conversion of 93% was obtained by esterifying PFAD with RH ash NiSO4/SiO2 catalyst under optimal reaction conditions.
Acid and biological pre-treatments of RHs
For the production of bioethanol, Klebsiella oxytoca ATCC 13182 was chosen as the bacterial strain. The bacterial culture was revived and kept in a nutrient agar slant at 4Â Â°C for later use.
Bioethanol
The production of biodiesel was increased by acid and biological pretreatments of RHs.
After acid and biological pretreatments of RHs, the amount of biodiesel was raised by 1.47 folds.
(S. Tiwari et al., 2022)
Pretreatment of RHs with InVO4 decorated TiO2 nanocomposite and anaerobic digestion of RHs to produce biogas
InVO4/TiO2 photocatalysts were used to enhance the biodegradability of RHs for the production of biogas
Methane (biogas)
The biodegradability of RHs was increased by the addition of an InVO4/TiO2 catalyst that ultimately enhanced the anaerobic digestion to produce more biogas
Pretreated RHs generated 2.8 times more biogas as compared to untreated RHs.
Liquid Hot Water and Steam Explosion pretreatments of RHs to produce bioethanol
High-carbohydrate biomass was hydrolyzed, releasing reducing sugars that are then fermented to produce bioethanol.
Bioethanol
Higher bioethanol yields were obtained by using pretreated RHs.
43.6% of bioethanol was obtained by using pretreated RHs.
Fermentation of insoluble solids of RH slurry to produce bioethanol
Strains of fungi and bacteria were used to hydrolyze the RHs and fermentation by using the CAT-1 strain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae to produce bioethanol.
Bioethanol
The yield of bioethanol was increased by using strains of fungi and bacteria during the hydrolysis process.
A total of 19.17Â g/L of bioethanol was produced after the fermentation of RHs.
Solid-state chemical pretreatment of RHs with HCl, NaOH, and C2H5OH
RHs were chemically pretreated with C2H5OH, NaOH, and HCl at 3 different concentrations i.e. 1, 3, and 5% at 100â120Â Â°C of temperature for 60Â min.
Methane (biogas)
Solid-state chemical pretreatment of RHs enhanced the production of biogas.
RHs pretreated with C2H5OH at 3% concentration and 100Â Â°C temperature produced the highest amount of biogas.
Two-stage fed-batch fermentation of RHs.

A hemicellulose-rich hydrolysate was produced by optimizing the alkaline fractionation of RH with NaOH to recover glucan with a high yield and to remove lignin and ash more quickly. The optimal conditions were determined by the researchers to be 150Â Â°C, 45Â min of reaction time, and 6% (w/v) of NaOH concentration.
Bioethanol
Higher yields of bioethanol were obtained by using a two-stage batch fermentation process.
RHs can be used to produce high-ethanol titers of 28.7Â g/L.
Thermo-chemical pretreatment of extracted algae and co-digestion with CH

NaOH was added in various concentrations (4, 6, and 8Â g) to 5Â g of de-oiled algal biomass. After that, the samples were prepared with de-oiled algae and CH and thoroughly mixed. All experiments were conducted in 500Â mL serum bottles with a working volume of 250Â mL.
Biogas (Methane)
Higher yields of biogas were obtained after thermo-chemical pretreatment of algae and co-digestion with CH.
The yield of biogas from pretreated algae along with CH was 60% higher than the yield of biogas from untreated algae.
Steam pretreatment of CH, peanut husk, and coffee cherry husk, enzymatic hydrolysis, and fermentation to produce bioethanol.

SphingobacteriumÂ sp. Ksn was used to produce crude lignocellulolytic enzymes. TheÂ SaccharomycesÂ cerevisiae and Candida tropicalisÂ were employed individually or as co-culture for fermentation of theÂ hydrolysate.
Bioethanol
Higher yields of bioethanol were obtained by steam pretreatments and the addition of cultures during the fermentation process.
A maximum of 20.61, 5.81, and 18.21Â g/L of ethanol were produced using steam-treated CH as the substrate by separate hydrolysis and fermentation.
Fermentation of MHs and RHs to produce bioethanol

The samples were crushed to powder by using a warring blender and a sieve with a mesh size of 0.5Â mm after two days of air drying. The ground sample was cleaned and stored after being free from debris and foreign objects.
Bioethanol
Low energy and mild environmental conditions were required to produce bioethanol from MHs and RHs.
After a 7-day fermentation period, RHs showed 68.67Â Â±Â 17.69Â g/L of ethanol and MHs showed 79.80Â Â±Â 0.93Â g/L of ethanol.

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Biodegradable film preparations from cereal-based husks.

row.entry: Cereal-based husks/Waste products
Processing conditions
Biopolymers/Packaging components
Film preparation/Packaging material formulation
characteristics
Main findings
References
WH fiber was treated with acetic anhydride and combined with PVC in different amounts, such as 10, 20, and 30%, and various composite samples were created.
Cellulose acetate
The calendaring method was used to create composites from PVC formulations combined with WH fiber.
Modulus drops with treatment, stiffness drops in composites treated with fibers, and plasticity rises.
In comparison to PVC and WH, the study shows a decrease in modulus for both the 20% and 30% formulations.

The pulps were dignified by using a 1.7% solution of sodium hypochlorite and a buffer solution of 300Â mL volume. Continuous stirring was carried out for 6Â h at 80Â Â°C. The sample was then filtered and dried at 40Â Â°C in an oven.
Cellulose Nanocrystals
Chitosan with a deacetylation level of 75%, corn cob, and CHs, as well as glycerol, were used in the formulation of biodegradable films.
An increase in mechanical properties was observed after the addition of CH fibers.
Films prepared by the addition of CH fibers showed a water activity of 0.65.
CHs were washed in deionized water and 1% w/v of NaOH solution had been used for bleaching.
Nanocellulose
H2SO4 solution was used to hydrolyze the fiber content and a supernatant solution was obtained from the cellulose nanocrystal suspension after centrifugation at 5000Â rpm.
Lower porosity and high surface roughness was observed.
Such composite membranes that have a higher mechanical strength and less porosity can be used for filtration and packaging purposes.
The TEOS-treated CH and PBS film was compressed to create the PBS thermo-coated CH formulation.
CH starch

The compression molding method was used at 160Â Â°C and 100Â bar pressure for 4Â min and a layer of thermo-coated CH was sandwiched to create the composite starch foam. The mold was then allowed to cool for 15Â min.
CH starch has a positive impact on the overall strength of the material formed and improves the property of water resistance
The highest performance was observed by the composite foams that had crosslinked tapioca starch laminar with 3% PBS-coated CH.
CHP and CH filament were each hydrolyzed by 88% fatty acids in a single step using a 500Â mL spherical flask. The flask was placed in an oil bath at 85Â Â°C for 1â5Â h.
Cellulose nanoparticles
First, the CHP and CH filaments were separated. Next, a comparative analysis of the effective conversion of CHP and CH filament to useful products was carried out using a sustainable method.
Cellulose nanoparticles with excellent thermal stability and high crystallinity were obtained that had high water resistance and barrier properties.
Cellulose nanoparticles obtained from CHP and CH filament showed good tensile strength and mechanical properties.
CHs were cleaned and then dried at 70Â Â°C in an oven, then ground into smaller, shorter fibers before being further treated with NaOH solution.
CH fiber
The treated CH fibers were combined by using HaakeRheomix equipment. Composites were created with CH fiber contents of 30, 40, 50, and 60%.
The composites produced from CH fiber exhibit good tensile strength and mechanical properties with less water absorption.
With the increase in fiber contents, tensile strength, and thermal stability have been increased.

The CHs were placed in an oven and dried at 65Â Â°C for 4Â h and subjected to high air pressure. The dried CH mass was then milled into strips with a transverse width of about 15Â mm. CHP was produced and CH fiber was extracted from it under magnetic stirring.
CH fiber
Biodegradable films were developed by the addition of CH fiber at various concentrations.
Composites containing 5% CH fiber contents showed an improvement in tensile strength.
CH fiber can be used to prepare biodegradable films and other packaging materials to preserve food products.
CHs were first cleaned, dried, crushed, and then screened through a mesh sieve with a 300 Î¼mpore size to obtain CH fiber.
CH fiber
Biocomposite films were created using a matrix having thermoplastic cornstarch in it, with CH fiber that served as the reinforcing filler.
With the addition of CH fiber, relative crystallinity, intermolecular H-bonding, and thermal stability were increased.

The addition of CH fiber improved the performance of biodegradable films. A decrease in the moisture content and density of the composite was observed and a soil burial test revealed more biodegradation.
CHs were washed with water and a plastic scraper was used to scratch the softened and swollen CHs to extract the fibers. Dried CH fibers were chemically processed to obtain finer fiber particles.
CH fibers
To create a masterbatch feedstock composite, a predetermined amount of processing aid, recycled polystyrene resin, and CH fibers were mixed using a Brabender internal mixer.
Higher melting viscosity was observed by the addition of CH fibers.
Increased CH fiber contents were required to obtain composite films of good quality.
CHs were uniformly grounded and pyrolyzed for 2Â h at 800Â Â°C, and heated at a rate of 5Â Â°C per minute. The CH ash was then sieved mechanically with a pore size of 20Â Î¼m to obtain silica.
Silica
The silica-based ceramic hollow membrane was made using CH ash. A silica interlayer was employed to construct thin film composites.
Lower transmission of light was shown by thin film composite membranes for all solutions.
CH is a source of silica and can be used to prepare packaging material for food items.
CHs were soaked in 5% NaOH solution to obtain CH fiber that was then rinsed with water and dried by air.
CH fiber
The CH fibers were combined to create a composite material.
The sound absorption capability was improved by the addition of CH fibers.
CH fiber can be used to prepare biodegradable packaging materials having good sound absorption properties
A mixture of hot benzene and ethanol was mixed with CHs for about 1Â h, and the process was repeated 3 times to obtain cellulose and nanocellulose.
Cellulose and nanocellulose
Hydrophobic membranes having silica were produced using surface coating and internal grafting techniques after the extraction of nano-cellulose from CHs.
The films prepared had a better surface, transparency, roughness, hydrophobic, and anti-fouling properties.
The internal grafted film has a 10.5% of silica, a light transmittance of 84.4%, and a 152.6Â° surface contact angle to the water.
(Q. Chen et al., 2020)
750Â g of RHs were processed in 3Â L of distilled water and cellulose extracts were concentrated under continuous stirring.
Cellulose
Starch-based films were prepared by using RH-based cellulose.
The starch-based films produced as a result of RH-based cellulose addition showed enhanced tensile properties and their elastic modulus was increased by 350%.
The biodegradable films showed better barrier properties and good tensile strength and were less transparent and brown.
100Â g of sifted RHs and 6% (w/v) of KOH were mixed and stirred continuously for 2Â h at 85Â Â°C. CMC was extracted by acid hydrolysis i.e. 4% (v/v) H2SO4 was used for hydrolysis.
CMC
Biofilms were prepared by mixing RH-based CMC, starch solution, glycerol, and water.
The solubility, moisture content, opacity, and mechanical strength were increased by the addition of RH-based CMC.
The blended film composed of RH-based CMC displayed greater elongation and tensile strength.
RHs were washed, cleaned, dried, and ground to make RHP have a particle size of <600Â Î¼m. RHP was then used to produce RH fiber.
RH fibers
Green composite films were produced from PLA, PBS, and RHs with the help of a twin-screw extruder.
Improved biodegradation, elongation, and impact strength properties were observed in PLA-RH composite films.
The impact strength and elongation properties of PLA-RH composite films were increased by the addition of RH fibers.
RHs were first washed and then dried at 110Â Â°C for about 2Â h. After that, it was dissolved in acid using a 1Â N HCl solution and nano-silica was extracted.
Nano-silica
RH-based nano-silica was used as a filler to prepare starch blended and starch phthalate biodegradable films.
The tensile properties of the films were enhanced by the addition of RH-based nano-silica.
Starch phthalate blended films demonstrated a higher biodegradation rate i.e. 14.8% in vegetable waste and 13.5%in garden soil.

RHs were first washed in clean water and then dried at 110Â Â°C in an oven for 24Â h. The dried RHs were exposed to an acid solution containing HNO3, HCl, and CH3COOH in varying amounts for 1.5Â h with continuous stirring.
Silica nanoparticles
Films were prepared by mixing RH-based silica nanoparticles, SPI, sorbitol, glycerol, and water.
The tensile and mechanical properties of the films were increased by the addition of RH-based silica nanoparticles as well as SPI.
Natural degradation property was observed in prepared composite films.
Silica nanoparticles were produced from RHs and a vacuum drying technique was used to remove physical and chemical absorbed species.
Silica nanoparticles
Various starch and modified nano-silica compositions were melted and blended. The blended mixture was then compressed and molded to prepare the films.
The addition of RH-based silica nanoparticles increased the tensile and mechanical properties of the biodegradable films.
The films prepared from RH-based silica nanoparticles showed natural degradation in garden soil.
RHs with a particle size of 16.59Â Î¼m were used to produce RH fibers.
RH fibers
RH fibers and glycerol were mixed to prepare the biocomposite films.
The mechanical strength of the biocomposite films was improved by the addition of RH fibers.
After a 6-month soil burial test, the composite films showed a 92% mass loss that demonstrated their biodegradability.
RHs were ground into a powder form and cellulose nanocrystals were extracted from them.
Cellulose nanocrystals
RH-based cellulose nanocrystals and cassava starch were mixed to prepare the films.
The tensile properties and thermal stability of the films were enhanced by the addition of RH-based cellulose nanocrystals.
The prepared films can be used as shopping bags and for packaging food products.
1Â M NaOH and 1Â M HNO3 were added to the RH powder. The RH cellulose fiber was extracted after filtration through a sieve (having a mesh size of 120Â Î¼m).
RH cellulose fiber
Biocomposite films were prepared by mixing RH cellulose fiber, thermoplastic starch, glycerol, and water.
The addition of RH cellulose fiber in biocomposite films produced elasticity and improved their tensile strength.
The biocomposite formed can be a reliable source for high-quality packaging supplies.
RHs were ground into a powder form and nanoparticles were separated from it.
RH nanoparticles
Biocomposite films were produced by mixing RH flour and PHB.
The films showed increased thermal and mechanical properties and low crystallinity after the addition of RH nanoparticles.
More affordable food packaging materials can be prepared by the utilization of RHs and their nanoparticles.
MCS was extracted from the RHs by using green extraction methods.
MCS
MCS and PVA were mixed and blended to prepare films.
Mechanical, O2 barrier and CO2-releasing properties were enhanced by the addition of RH-based MCS.
CO2 releasing property of the film made it suitable for the storage of meat products.
RHs were washed, dried, and ground into a powder form to extract RH fibers.
RH fibers
RH fibers and PLA were mixed and composite films were produced with the help of the compression-molding technique.
The tensile strength, impact strength, tensile modulus, and hardness of the biocomposite films were increased by the addition of RH fibers.
RH fibers can be used to make packaging materials with good thermal and mechanical strength.
RHs were delignified to produce cellulose and Acetobacter xylinum cellulose (bacterial cellulose) was also added to strengthen it.
Cellulose
Biocomposite films were produced by mixing RH cellulose, bacterial cellulose of A .xylinum, chitosan, maleic anhydride, and glycerol by using the compression molding technique.
The mechanical strength of the biocomposite films was increased after the addition of RH cellulose.
RH-based cellulose can be used to produce biodegradable films of good mechanical strength.
RHs were washed with distilled water and treated with NaOH solution to extract cellulose nanoparticles.
Cellulose nanoparticles
Films were produced by mixing RH-based cellulose nanoparticles, glycerol, and water.
Tensile strength, toughness, and elongation properties were increased by the addition of RH-based cellulose nanoparticles.
RH-based cellulose nanoparticles can be used to produce biodegradable films of good strength, toughness, and mechanical properties.
RHs were cleaned with deionized water, oven dried, and ground into a powder form to extract RH nanoparticles.
RH nanoparticles
Biocomposite films were produced by mixing RH nanoparticles and propylene-grafted maleic anhydride with the help of the compression molding technique.
The thermal and mechanical strengths of the biocomposite films were improved after the addition of RH nanoparticles.
RH nanoparticles can be used to prepare water-resistant packaging stuff with improved thermal and mechanical strengths.
RHs were subjected to an incineration process after being treated with an acid to extract silica from them.
Silica
Biocomposite films were produced by mixing RH-based silica, organically modified nano clay, and PLA by using the solvent casting method.
Films produced by the addition of RH-based silica showed water barrier properties.
RH-based silica can be used to produce water-resistant packaging materials.
RHs were subjected to alkaline treatment, bleached, and acid hydrolysis to extract nanocellulose from them.
Nanocellulose
Films were prepared by mixing RH-based nanocellulose and potato starch with the use of the solution casting method.
The properties of transparency and mechanical strength were improved by the addition of RH-based nanocellulose.
RH-based nanocellulose can be used to produce packaging materials with high mechanical strength and transparency.

RHs were subjected to an organosolvation pretreatment (a treatment in which organic solvent is mixed with an inorganic acid catalyst to break lignin or hemicellulose bonds) to extract lignin from them.
Lignin
Films were prepared by mixing RH-based lignin, PLA, and organic solvents (chloroform and acetone) by using the electrospinning technique.
Thermal stability was increased by the addition of RH-based lignin and films showed antioxidant characteristics.
RH-based lignin can be used to produce antioxidant and thermally stable packaging materials.
RHs were washed, dried, and ground into a powder form to obtain nanoparticles from them.
RH nanoparticles
Films were prepared by mixing RH-based nanoparticles and PVA with the use of the solution casting method.
Thermal and mechanical strengths were increased by the addition of RH-based nanoparticles. Moreover, the films produced also showed antimicrobial properties.

RH-based nanoparticles in combination with PVA can be used to produce packaging materials with anti-bacterial characteristics that will be effective against both gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria.
BHs were first subjected to enzymatic and chemical pretreatments and then acid hydrolysis was performed to extract the cellulose nanocrystals from them.
Cellulose nanocrystals
Films were produced by mixing BH-based cellulose nanocrystals, PVA, glacial acetic acid, and water.
Thermal, mechanical, and optical properties were improved after the addition of BH-based cellulose nanocrystals.
The films produced by the addition of BH-based cellulose nanocrystals inhibit the growth of bacteria and fungi within the food items.
BHs were washed, dried, and ground into a powder form. Grafted BH was extracted from them by using a Soxhlet extraction method.
Grafted BH
Films were produced by mixing grafted BH, PVA, glycerol, and water.
Mechanical and water-resistant properties of the films were improved after the addition of grafted BH.
Grafted BH can be used to make water-resistant packaging stuff.
BHs were washed, dried in an oven, and ground into a powder form. Then the powder of BHs was subjected to acid hydrolysis after an alkaline pretreatment to extract cellulose nanocrystals from them.
Cellulose nanocrystals
Films were produced by mixing BH-based cellulose nanocrystals, PVA, and water.
The tensile strength of the films was improved after the addition of BH-based cellulose nanocrystals.
BH-based cellulose nanocrystals can be used to produce packaging stuff with better tensile strength and improved mechanical properties.
A redox initiator was used for graft copolymerization of Oleic acid onto the BH.
Grafted BH
Films were produced by mixing grafted BH, PVA, and water.
The mechanical strength of the films was increased by the addition of grafted BH.
Grafted BH was used in PVA composite films as a reinforcement material, resulting in higher mechanical strength of the films.
MHs were washed, dried in an oven, macerated, and milled by using a pulverizing machine (a machine used for grinding purposes). After that MH fiber was extracted from them.
MH fiber
Films were prepared by mixing MH fiber, PLA, and water.
The mechanical strength of the films was increased after the addition of MH fiber.

Increasing the MH fiber in the preparation of films enhanced the property of biodegradation as confirmed by the soil burial test. Hence MH fibers can be used to make packaging stuff with increased mechanical as well as biodegradation properties.

head.ce:title: Utilization of cereal-based husks to achieve sustainable development goals: Treatment of wastewater, biofuels, and biodegradable packaging

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Food waste management (FWM) has gained much attention over the past few years in industries, research institutions, and national and international organizations due to its significant potential to produce valuable products and control environmental pollution. Finding the sustainable approaches to utilize these waste materials is a current focus of many researchers.

This review aims to explore the potential of cereal-based husks from 5 major cereal grains (wheat, rice, corn, barley, and millet) to achieve goals 6 (clean water and sanitation), 7 (affordable and clean energy), 9 (industry, innovation, and infrastructure), and 12 (responsible consumption and production) of the 17 sustainable development goals (SDGs) set out by the united nations to make the world more healthy and developed with minimum environmental pollution.

Cereal-based husks can be utilized to make adsorbents to remove heavy metals, dyes, antibiotics, pesticides, and petrol contaminants from wastewater. These husks can be utilized to produce clean and affordable energy alternatives such as biogas (methane), organic bio-oil, biodiesel, and bioethanol. Moreover, the biopolymeric matrices of these husks can be efficiently used to make bioplastics, biocomposite films, biodegradable foams, and packaging paper for food and other industries.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: The United Nations has targeted the reduction of food losses in both production and supply chains by 2030 in its SDGs (Target 12.3). A significant amount of food waste is discarded from food industries along their production, processing, and supply chain (Caldeira et al., 2019) which contributes significantly to environmental pollution, economic inequality, and climate change (FAO, 2019). Massive research efforts have been directed in recent years to find out the sustainable approaches to utilize food waste products to recover energy in the form of biofuels, bioconversion of food waste into marketable products, and reduce environmental pollution using food waste ingredients (Bilal et al., 2018).

The presence of heavy metals in water is a critical issue as it can cause severe toxicity in living organisms leading to serious illnesses. Due to the presence of toxic heavy metals in the water streams, water resources are under stress all over the world. The food chain is also badly affected due to the occurrence of heavy metals in water (Khalil et al., 2020). Dyes and colors eliminated from textile industries in the form of textile wastewater get mixed with our aquatic freshwater and affects aquatic life. These dyes also pass through the entire food chain as seafood is a good source of nutrition (Kheddo et al., 2020). Antibiotics are a threat to our ecosystem because of their relatively stable structure, complex biological activity, and resistance to biodegradation. Contamination of water with antibiotics transforms antibiotic resistance genes and produces composite pollutants by the combination of antibiotics with other pollutants present in wastewater that are very hazardous to the health of living organisms (Yang et al., 2020). Similarly, organophosphorus pesticides penetrates deep into the soil and pollute the groundwater due to their high water solubility (Raju et al., 2019). Exposure to these pesticides for a long time in high doses can cause chromosomal aberrations, carcinogenic effects, and hypoimmunity (Sinha & Banda, 2018). Food waste is also a source of renewable energy with a significant potential to produce biofuels for heat, transportation, and electricity. Biofuels produced from food waste materials like biogas, biodiesel, and bioethanol lead to a reduction in harmful nitrogen and sulfur oxides and are thus beneficial to the climate. The production of environmentally friendly and cleaner fuels as an alternative to the available fossil fuels is a much-needed solution to meet the high energy demand sustainably (Popp et al., 2021). Plastic materials have vast use for packaging because of their resistance to mechanical and environmental factors, flexibility, excellent printability, and low cost. But these plastic materials have detrimental effects on the environment as they degrade over the decades and release harmful chemicals which can deteriorate the quality of food. Hence, it is safer to use biodegradable materials for packaging purposes as compared to plastics while considering environmental and health concerns (Horodytska et al., 2018). Previous investigations have revealed numerous possibilities for utilization of food waste products such as the formulation of fertilizers, composts (Ahmad et al., 2022; Ahouangninou et al., 2022; Hayat et al., 2022), and animal feed (Fazili et al., 2021; Ismael et al., 2022; Zaki et al., 2021), development of functional foods and nutraceuticals (Lavelli, 2021), preparation of biodegradable packaging (Aouat et al., 2021; Hammajam et al., 2019; Mittal et al., 2020; Sirichalarmkul and Kaewpirom, 2021; Tan et al., 2022), production of biofuels (S. B. Tiwari et al., 2021; Embong et al., 2021; Shankar et al., 2019; AZ et al., 2021), and treatment of wastewater (Habiba et al., 2022; Dan et al., 2021; Sanka et al., 2020; Akhayere et al., 2020; Prajapati et al., 2022).

Cereal-based husks are mainly composed of cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin. Wheat husk (WH) contains 36% of cellulose, 18% of hemicellulose, and 16% of lignin (Santos et al., 2019). Rice husk (RH) is composed of 35% cellulose, 25% hemicellulose, and 20% lignin (Tiwari et al., 2022). Corn husk (CH), barley husk (BH), and millet husk (MH) also have cellulose, hemicelluloses, and lignin as their main constituents (Chen et al., 2023; Fortunati et al., 2016; Gairola et al., 2022). Cereal-based husks are separated as waste in cereal processing industries when cereal grains are cleaned, dehulled, and milled into various cereal flours. These byproducts are produced as a waste of cereal processing industries in about 70â80 million tons worldwide every year (Chen et al., 2023). This review describes the utilization of cereal-based husks like WH, RH, CH, BH, and MH to make adsorbents for the removal of Hg, Pb, Cd, Cr, Co, Fe, Ni, Cu, and other heavy metals, dyes like reactive blue (RB), methylene blue (MB), basic red (BR), basic blue (BB), crystal violet (CV) and tartrazine, antibiotics like ciprofloxacin (CIP), beta-lactam amoxicillin, and beta-lactam cefixime, pesticides like 2,4-dichlorophenoxy acetic acid (2,4-D), and other petrol contaminants from the wastewater. The production of biogas, biodiesel, bioethanol, and manufacturing of bioplastics, biodegradable films, packaging paper, and biodegradable foams from cereal-based husks are also described in detail with an aim of effective cereal waste management.

The European Union (EU) Directive 2018/851/EC imposed a hierarchical approach to the management of waste materials discarded from various industries. According to which recovery, re-use, disposal, recycling, or prevention of waste from accumulation should be described from top to bottom in detail by adopting a waste hierarchy approach (European Parliament and Council of the European Union, 2018). In numerous papers published on the topic of waste management, the products that are fit for human consumption are separated by a dotted line from those products that are unfit for human consumption. In some studies, economically viable byproducts are separated from uneconomical ones. Some researchers also categorized the byproducts into various categories based on their best place of utilization i.e. food fortificant or biopreservative, animal feed, fertilizers, non-food products, and biofuels, etc. (Lavelli, 2021). In this paper, the source of cereal-based husks and their sustainable utilization is described by adopting a simple waste hierarchy approach as shown in Fig. 1 .

Goal 6 of SDGs focuses on clean water and sanitation. Water is a vital component of our environment without it, life becomes impossible. So there is a great need to conserve water resources and make them free from harmful contaminants. Sustainable approaches to treat industrial wastewater by the utilization of cereal-based husks are discussed below in detail.

Amen et al. (2020) performed research on the adsorptive removal of heavy metal ions like Cd+2 and Pb+2 from wastewater by using biochar made from RH, corncob, and wheat straw. The characterization of biochar revealed that it had mixed redox as well as inert surface functional groups that proved helpful in decomposing the contaminants in wastewater because they can donate and accept electrons and form linkages with the chemical pollutants present in the wastewater. The biochar made from RH, corncob, and wheat straw showed an amorphous structure with very less abnormalities, hygroscopic with exceptional thermal stability even maintaining its significant weight at a temperature of 700Â Â°C, and showed 94.73%, 93.68%, and 95.78% adsorption of Cd+2 and 96.41%, 95.38%, and 96.92% adsorption of Pb+2 from the wastewater. In another study, Panigrahi and Narayanan (2020) transformed WHs into an activated carbon after soaking the ground form of WHs in 30% of H3PO4(WHs were converted into activated charcoal by a process of pyrolysis) and examined the adsorption of Cr, As, Pb, and Hg by using that activated carbon from the wastewater of textile industry. For batch tests, 10Â g of WHs was used for 200Â mL of textile effluent and the pH of the samples was adjusted from 4.5 to 7.5. The results showed that the concentration of As was reduced from 0.034 to 0.024Â mg/L, the concentration of Hg was reduced from 3.86 to 1.32Â mg/L, the concentration of Pb was reduced from 0.018 to 0.016Â mg/L while the concentration of Cr remained same at pH 7.5.

Sanka et al. (2020) produced biochar after pyrolysis of CHs and RHs at 500, 600, and 700Â Â°C of temperatures and employed that biochar for the removal of heavy metal ions from industrial wastewater. An atomic adsorption spectrophotometer was used to measure the initial metal ion concentrations in the wastewater and the residual levels after the application of biochar. Carbonization of RHs at 600Â Â°C showed the best removal efficiencies for Pb (>90%), Fe (90%), and Cr (65%) while the carbonization of CHs at 600Â Â°C produced the poorest removal efficiencies for Pb (slightly >35%) and Cr (only 20%). Rice husk biochar (RHB) showed a better capability of removing heavy metals from wastewater as compared to corn husk biochar (CHB). Gheitasi et al. (2022) produced thiol magnetic activated carbon adsorbent from beer BHs after magnetizing the activated carbon with Fe3O4 by using dual stage activation process and employed that adsorbent to remove Hg (II) ions from the wastewater. The results showed that about 99.44% of the Hg (II) ions were removed from the wastewater by 0.4Â g/L of adsorbent dosage at pH 6 and a contact time of 60Â min under optimum conditions. In another study, Prajapati et al. (2022) used great millet husk (GMH) to synthesize adsorbents by thermal and chemical modification of the GMH and examined the removal of Cr (VI) from synthetic wastewater. In a chemical modification of the GMH, concentrated H2SO4 was used to treat raw GMH which increased its porosity and heterogeneity on the surface. The results showed that the maximum removal of Cr (VI) was 16Â mg/g with thermally treated GMH (TT-GMH) at pH 1, the adsorbent dosage of 4Â g/L, 25Â Â°C temperature, 150Â revolutions per minute (RPM) shaking speed, and contact time of 150Â min while the maximum removal of Cr (VI) was 22.21Â mg/g with chemically treated GMH (CT-GMH) at pH 2 and contact time of 120Â min. CT-GMH showed more Cr (VI) removal efficiency as compared to the TT-GMH.

Vasu et al. (2020) used WH as a biosorption medium for the removal of dyes especially RB 19 and RB 195 from the textile wastewater. Spectrophotometer was used to analyze the dyes colorimetrically present in the wastewater. The results showed that 68% removal of RB 19 and 70% removal of RB 195 were obtained at a contact time of 90Â min with adsorbent made from WH. Heng et al. (2021) synthesized silica (SiO2) and carbon dots (CDs) from RHs and produced CD/SiO2 composite by impregnating the CDs on SiO2 through a hydrothermal synthesis reaction. Ultrafiltration (UF) membranes were developed by using a series of CD/SiO2 composites and employed for the removal of dyes from wastewater. CD/SiO2 additive enhanced the membrane properties, negative surface charge, pore distribution, pore size, and hydrophilicity of the UF membranes. As a result, 50.54% of dye removal was obtained with 2.5Â wt% of CD/SiO2 membrane as compared to the 14.52% with the pure membrane (CD/SiO2). In another study, Quansah et al. (2020) thermally treated RHs and produced an adsorbent to remove cationic dyes like CV and MB from wastewater. The results showed that the thermally treated RHs at 75Â Â°C had higher adsorption capacity as compared to those RHs that were treated at higher temperatures ranging from 300 to 700Â Â°C. The adsorption capacity for CV was 25.46Â mg/g and 24.48Â mg/g for MB according to the Langmuir isotherm model. The adsorption capacity was increased by increasing the pH from 4 to 10.

Garamon (2019) prepared low-cost adsorbents by activation and carbonization of BHs and RHs, used them in aqueous solutions, and examined the adsorption of Brilliant Green dye on activated carbon produced by a chemical activation process. The adsorption capacity of both BHs and RHs was increased by activation and carbonization because it increased the carbon pores responsible for the adsorption of dyes. The results showed that activated barley husk (AC-BH) removed 90% and activated rice husk (AC-RH) removed 94% of Brilliant Green dye from aqueous solutions while the adsorbents prepared without activation and carbonization showed low adsorption capacity. In another study, Musa et al. (2022) carried out the grafting process for MHs by using Ceric ammonium nitrate and Acrylonitrile as initiators and used grafted MH to synthesize poly-amidoxime ligand for the adsorption of Congo red dye from aqueous solutions. The results showed that the synthesized poly-amidoxime ligand removed 94.89% of Congo red dye at an adsorbent dosage of 0.3Â g for 60Â mg/L of initial concentration of dye and contact time of 45Â min.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Removal of antibiotics, pesticides, and related compounds
ce:section.ce:para: Habiba et al. (2022) used a simple intercalation approach and prepared a wheat husk biochar (WHB) loaded with cinnamic acid (CA) to remove hazardous organic pollutants from aqueous solutions. Batch experiments and density functional theory (DFT) calculations were used to study the removal mechanisms of MB and CIP by employing WHB modified with CA (WHC/CA). The results showed that 96.52% of MB and 94.03% of CIP were removed by using WHC/CA. In another study, Franco et al. (2021) used husks of buckwheat (Fagopyrum esculentum), modified them by treating them with H2SO4, and examined their adsorption capacity to remove a herbicide 2,4-D from aqueous solutions. The results showed that 45% of 2,4-D was removed by using modified husks of buckwheat.

Okoya et al. (2020) prepared RHB as an adsorbent and evaluated its performance to remove chlorpyrifos from pesticide-polluted water. The performance of RHB to remove chlorpyrifos was also compared with the performance of commercial activated carbon (CAC). The adsorption efficiency of RHB to adsorb chlorpyrifos from polluted water was assessed by batch adsorption studies. The results showed that RHB removed 94.5% of chlorpyrifos while CAC removed 93.7% removal of chlorpyrifos. RHB performed more efficiently than CAC to remove chlorpyrifos from pesticide-polluted water.

Bhatti, Mahmood, et al. (2020a) used BHs as cellulosic biomass, and produced biocomposites by using polypyrrole (PPY), polyaniline (PANI), and sodium alginate with BH (NaAlg/BH) and examined the performance of that biocomposites to remove 2,4-dichlorophenol (2,4-DCP) from aqueous media. The results showed that by using 0.05Â g of composite dose, maximum sorption of 2,4-DCP ranged from 7.55 to 24.57Â mg/g from 25Â mg/L initial concentration of 2,4-DCP at 30Â Â°C temperature, contact time of 120Â min and pH range from 7 to 10. The utilization of cereal-based husks for the treatment of wastewater is discussed in detail in Table 1 and Fig. 2 .

Goal 7 of the SDGs focuses on affordable and clean energy. The fossil fuels used in automobiles for transportation purposes emit harmful oxides of sulfur and nitrogen, hydrocarbons, and other harmful chemicals in the fresh air that are very toxic to our health. Biofuels are a possible solution to this life-threatening problem. The production of biofuels from cereal-based husks is discussed below in detail.

Sun et al. (2019) examined the biochemical methane potential (BMP) of WHs before and after pretreatment with liquid digestate (LD) soaking. The yield of methane gas was increased by 91% from 68Â mL/g VS (yield of biogas in terms of volatile solids) to 130.0Â mL/g VS with the use of LD soaking pretreatment. LD pretreatment was successful in improving the anaerobic digestion of WHs.Syafrudin et al. (2020) utilized RH waste and studied the impact of changes in the grind size of RH particles on the production of biogas during liquid anaerobic digestion (L-AD). The production of biogas is computed and expressed as ml/grTS. The grinding size of 10 mesh gave 54.95 mL/grTS, 18 mesh gave 44.86 mL/grTS, 35 mesh gave 58.13 mL/grTS, and 60 mesh gave 72.14 mL/grTS of biogas. In another study, Olugbemide et al. (2020) studied the production of biogas from RHs by using 1, 3, and 5% concentrations of NaOH, HCl, and C2H5OH at 100â120Â Â°C for 60Â min. The ethanol-pretreated sample showed the highest production of biogas at 100Â Â°C, followed by NaOH and HCl pretreated samples. The biogas yields for pretreated samples with HCl, NaOH, and C2H5OH were 32.26, 60.89, and 67.32 mL/gVS respectively at 100Â Â°C.

Murali et al. (2019) produced biogas from CHs and Azolla (feedstocks) and studied the performance of that biogas in a compression ignition (CI) diesel engine. The exhaust gas emissions were also studied in the same research. The results showed that the ignition latency of the CI engine became shortened when biogas produced from CHs and Azolla was burnt in it. The exhaust gas emitted from the CI engine showed lower smoke and hydrocarbons as compared to petroleum fuels.

Santos et al. (2019) used thermo-catalytic reforming (TCR) technology to convert WHs into fuels in a 2Â kg/h continuous pilot-scale reactor. Out of 100Â wt% of the feedstock, the amount of bio-oil produced was 5.8%, gas was 29.6%, char was 21.7%, aqueous phase liquids were 32.8%, and the remaining 10.1% were losses during the process. The bio-oil obtained from the WH waste had a 29.9Â mg KOH/g value of total acid number (TAN) and a 145.2Â cSt value of viscosity. It was suggested to blend the bio-oil obtained from the WH waste with fossil crude oil to use as a direct engine fuel. In another study, Hazmi et al. (2021) utilized RHB to produce a bifunctional magnetic nano-catalyst that was further doped with 20% of KOH and 5% of Ni2O (RCH/K2O-20%/Ni-5%) by using impregnation procedures and evaluated the catalytic ability of the nano-catalyst formed by transesterifying the used cooking oil. The parameters including the amount of nano-catalyst and methanol oil were optimized in a 12:1 ratio and biodiesel was produced through a transesterification reaction at 65Â Â°C and 2Â h of reaction time. The catalyst was reused for up to 5 reaction cycles, with the last cycles yielding 70% of biodiesel. The results showed that the RHB can be used to produce magnetic nano-catalysts to enhance the yield of biodiesels and for purification and separation procedures.

Panithasan et al. (2020) performed research by forming the blend of Jatropha biodiesel with RH nanoparticles and evaluated the performance of that blend in a single cylinder four-stroke diesel engine. The exhaust gas emitted from the diesel engine was also evaluated after the burning of the blended biodiesel. The results showed that a 0.2% addition of RH particles to 20% of the Jatropha methyl ester-diesel blend improved the combustion properties, and performance characteristics and lowered the exhaust emissions of harmful gases to the environment. The hydrocarbon emissions were reduced by 23.7%, carbon monoxide (CO) was reduced by 18.3%, and smoke opacity was reduced by 21.4%.

Tiwari et al. (2022) synthesized bioethanol from RHs that are lignocellulosic and considered an inexpensive agricultural waste by using Klebsiella oxytoca ATCC 13182 (American type culture collection) bacterial strain and also analyzed the effect of different pretreatment strategies applied during the process. The results revealed that the production of bioethanol was 32.61Â Â±Â 0.45Â g/L after 48â72Â h of incubation at pH 7 and 36Â Â°C of temperature. Out of all the biological and acid pretreatment strategies applied during the process, the addition of Aspergillus niger enhanced the production of bioethanol up to1.47 folds (47.98Â Â±Â 1.25Â g/L). In another study, MontipÃ³ et al. (2019) separated the liquid and solid fractions of uncatalyzed steam-exploded RH slurry, and hydrolyzed the liquor efficiently by using an enzymatic complex obtained from S1M29 strain of Penicillium echinulatum (fungi) and NRRL B-30929 strain of Lactobacillus buchneri (bacteria), and subjected it to the saccharification and fermentation processes by using CAT-1 strain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae to produce bioethanol. As a result, 19.17Â g/L of ethanol and 12.69Â g/L of lactic acid were produced.

Shankar et al. (2019) utilized husks of corn, peanut, and coffee cherry in a low-cost saccharification process in which lignocellulolytic enzymes produced by Sphingobacteriumsp. Ksn was used to produce ethanol. The husks were pretreated with NaOH and H2SO4 before the enzymatic hydrolysis. CH was found to be an optimal substrate for enzymatic hydrolysis to produce fermentable sugars. Saccharomyces cerevisiae and Candida tropicalis were used separately as well as in a co-culture for the fermentation of the hydrolysate that was produced by the enzymatic breakdown of steam-treated husks. The maximum amount of ethanol produced using an enzyme-based hydrolysate of steam-treated CH taken as the substrate was 20.61, 5.81, and 18.21Â g/L, whereas 20.66 and 5.85Â g/L were obtained after 72Â h of fermentation from the corresponding immobilized yeast cells. The production of biofuels from cereal-based husks is described in detail in Table 2 . The commercial and environmental benefits of biofuels are described in Fig. 3 .

Goal 9 of the SDGs focuses on industry, innovation, and infrastructure and goal 12 focuses on responsible consumption and production. In industries, plastics are frequently used for packaging their goods. The extensive use of plastics results in great stress on our soil because of its low biodegradability and difficulty in its recycling. Bioplastics made from natural resources can be used for packaging industrial products. So the production of bioplastics and biodegradable materials by utilizing food waste products for packaging purposes is a responsible production and the replacement of traditional plastics with bioplastics is a great innovation. The production of bioplastics, biodegradable films, packaging paper, and biodegradable foams for packaging purposes is discussed below in detail.

Environmentally friendly materials known as bioplastics have become increasingly important for reducing the amount of conventional plastics-related pollution in the world. Karaca et al. (2022) studied the simultaneous extraction of crystal biogenic silica and cellulose fiber from the RHs to develop composite bioplastic films that were based on cellulose and reinforced with silica for use in packaging applications. The developed bioplastic sheets showed better tensile strength and their biodegradability in soil ranged from 25.5% to 55.7% when observed after 21 days. The above-observed range of biodegradability is much greater as compared to conventional plastic materials. In another study, Datta et al. (2019) functionalized the extracted nano-silica RH by its interaction with hydrophobic low-density polyethylene, 3-aminopropyltrimethoxysilane. The insertion of this surface-modified hydrophobic nano-silica (contact angleÂ =Â 97Â°) into its matrix improved the mechanical and optical properties of low-density polyethylene and starch-blended biodegradable films as compared to pure nano-silica blended films of the same composition. The formed homogenized blend showed a tear strength of 155.5Â N/mm and tensile strength of 10.03Â MPa as per mechanical and microstructure testing. By increasing the amount of RH-based nano-silica, the degradation rate of the films was also improved.

Choque-Quispe et al. (2022) developed an edible film using activated cellulose nanocrystals produced from CHs, glycerin, and potato starch. 4 film formulations containing 0.0â0.12% of cellulose nanocrystals, 2.6â4.4% of potato starch, and 3.0â4.2% of glycerin were produced by the thermoforming process at 60Â Â°C. The cellulose nanocrystals based on CHs enhanced the mechanical and thermal properties of the films. Z. Chen et al. (2023) used deep eutectic solvent (DES) treatment after mild alkaline treatment supported by sonication to fractionate the lignocellulosic components in CH. The fractionated cellulose diffused steadily in water and nano-sheets were prepared after the process of ball-milling. The combination of nano-cellulose and nano-hemicellulose showed a strong synergistic reinforcing effect and gas barrier properties. The produced nanosheets showed 2.2 times higher tensile strength and 1.7 times more breakage elongation in comparison with virgin alginate film. Zhang et al. (2022) developed CH-based plastic after the delignification of CHs. The developed CH-based plastic showed Young's modulus of 7.8Â GPa, mechanical strength of 118Â MPa, and 86% light transmittance which revealed its potential to replace conventional and non-biodegradable plastics. In another study, Mittal et al. (2020) demonstrated the potential of composite sheets composed of polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)/starch and cellulose based on BH as a packaging material. To cross-link the PVA/starch matrix with urea formaldehyde, BH was grafted using palmitic acid in the presence of redox initiators. By the addition of grafted BH to a cross-linked PVA/starch matrix, the mechanical and water barrier properties of the films were improved. The films produced also showed an increase in their biodegradation rate.

Gairola et al. (2022) obtained fiber from barnyard millet husks (BMH) and finger millet husks (FMH) and evaluated their physical, chemical, and morphological characteristics. After fiber characterization, composites were produced by using an injection molding technique. The results revealed that FMH-reinforced composites showed stronger mechanical properties as compared to BMH-reinforced composites while BMH-reinforced composites showed higher flame resistance and thermal stability. It had been suggested to use both husks to produce thermoplastic composites. In another study, Sivamurugan et al. (2022) obtained biosilica particles from FMH, and high-toughness epoxy composites were produced for packaging purposes by the addition of FMH-based biosilica particles and coconut rachilla fiber. The results indicated that the addition of FMH-based biosilica particles enhanced the flexural strength, tensile strength, impact strength, and hardness of the epoxy composites. The preparation of biodegradable films from cereal-based husks is described in Table 3 . The common methods and techniques involved in the preparation of biodegradable films are described in Fig. 4 .

Bhardwaj et al. (2022) utilized CH and sugarcane bagasse (SB) taken in varying amounts as lignocellulosic materials, produced packaging paper through soda pulping, and enhanced their functionalities through emulsion coatings of chitosan and beeswax-chitosan. The results showed that chitosan coating improved the barrier properties of packaging paper against moisture, water vapors, and air by up to 85% and beeswax-chitosan coated papers showed longer absorbancy time as compared to the untreated samples. In another study, KÃ¤rkÃ¶nen et al. (2022) examined the BHs and oat hulls for their chemical makeup, fiber length, and mycotoxin levels to reveal their potential to make packaging paper and paperboard. BHs and oat hulls were refined by using a disc refiner to produce fibrillation and laboratory sheets were produced by mixing BHs, oat hulls, and softwood pulp. The results showed that the paper produced by the addition of BHs and oat hulls had good tensile strength and fulfilled the same quality requirements as that of commercial paper available in the market.

Sun et al. (2023) produced an environmentally friendly foam composite by utilizing the RHs and maleic hydride grafted polylactic acid (MAH-g-PLA) as biodegradable ingredients. The foam composite showed a bending strength of 28.85Â MPa and tensile strength of 6.99Â MPa with good thermal stability. The chemical grafting between cellulose and PLA results in a denser structure of the foam composite and improved its mechanical, thermal, and water resistance properties. Spada et al. (2020) used 20%, 40%, and 60% of RH proportions to make foams for the storage of cherry tomatoes by using a thermopressing technique and compared them with those foams that were produced from only starch (without RH proportions). The results revealed that the foams produced by the addition of 40 and 60% of RH proportions absorb less water and the formulation made with 60% RH proportion showed higher flexural strength and lower water absorption capacity (WAC), making it suitable for storage of cherry tomatoes. In another study, Phiriyawirut et al. (2021) used CH as a reinforcement material to produce tapioca starch laminated composite foams from polybutylene succinate (PBS) and glyoxal crosslink-tapioca starch by using a compression molding technique. The results showed that crosslinked tapioca starch laminar composite foams had the maximum water resistance properties and impact strength with 3% PBS-coated CH.

Now it is a great need of the present day to adopt some sustainable approaches so that while making overall progress in the world, the level of environmental pollution can be also minimized efficiently. The biopolymeric matrices of cereal-based husks including WH, RH, CH, BH, and MH made them suitable for the preparation of adsorbants capable of removing heavy metals such as Cd, Cu, Cr, Co, Fe, Ni, Pb, and Hg, dyes such as reactive blue (RB 19 &RB 195), basic red (BR09 & BB41), methylene blue (MB), Congo red, crystal violet (CV), and tartrazine, pesticides like 2,4-D, antibiotics such as CIP, beta-lactam amoxicillin, and beta-lactam cefixime, and petrol contaminants from industrial wastewater. These husks can also be biotransformed into valuable products like biogas, biodiesel, and bioethanol as safe fuels for both our transportation and the environment. The biofuels produced from cereal-based husks burn smoothly in the combustible engines of automobiles and the exhaust gases emitted from automobiles after burning these biofuels are free from harmful oxides of sulfur and nitrogen. The cellulose, starch, fibers, nano-silica, nanocrystals, and other such useful constituents of these husks can efficiently be used to make bioplastics, biodegradable films, biodegradable foams, and packaging paper for various industries, especially the food industry. In the end, it is highly recommended to utilize food waste products as cheap sources for the treatment of industrial wastewater to remove harmful chemical pollutants before discharging it to freshwater streams, pay attention to producing biofuels for our transportation and bioplastics for our packaging purposes.
